text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single column of calendrical text on left with alternating coloured initials; wide red frame border enclosing text and two circular marginal miniatures on right; historiated initial at top left interrupts text block; clear visual hierarchy with large gold initial, secondary coloured initials, and smaller miniatures

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata with red rubrication and occasional Latin abbreviations

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf reserved for the main historiated initial and medallion backgrounds; blue and red alternated in smaller initials and frame; green used sparingly in costume to enliven scene; layered pigment application with white highlighting; colour hierarchy emphasizes the calendar structure and marginal imagery

features: vertical alignment of two circular medallions in right margin
central placement of figures within each medallion
balanced use of red and blue in border and initials
dominant historiated initial anchoring upper left

decorative_elements: historiated initial 'KL' with foliate ornament and gold ground
red frame border with internal white line
circular medallion frames in blue and red
alternating red and blue smaller initials
column of coloured day letters A–G

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill pen work with varying line weights for contours and foliage details
drawing_technique.shading_method: Minimal hatching; modelling achieved through layered pigment and white highlights
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Flat medieval spatial treatment with hierarchical scaling; no unified vanishing point

scene_relationships.subject: Labour of February: man warming hands by brazier
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Leads into the zodiacal sign as complementary monthly iconography
visual_connections: Both scenes set within identical circular medallions
Gold background continuous across both frames
Balanced use of azurite blue and vermillion red

scene_relationships.subject: Zodiac sign of Pisces: two fish swimming in opposite directions
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Completes the month emblem without further continuation
visual_connections: Symmetrical placement beneath the labour scene

visual_continuity: Consistent colour palette of blue, red and gold

content_theme.scene_description: Upper medallion depicts a single male figure kneeling upon a green plinth inside a circular gold background. He is clad in a green tunic and brown hooded cloak, hood up, hands extended toward a small three-legged brazier painted in brown with stylized orange flames. The figure’s posture is bent forward at the waist, head turned in three-quarter profile, rendered with fluid pen lines and flat modelling. The brazier rests on a tiled floor suggested by partial green bands. Below, in a matching medallion, two fish swim in counterpoise: one painted in green, the other in ochre, their bodies outlined in black and overlaid with gold highlights. Both scenes occupy the right margin, framed by a narrow red and blue border that echoes the main frame, creating a cohesive seasonal and zodiacal programme for February.

secular: Man kneeling warming hands at brazier wearing hooded cloak and tunic
symbolic: Pisces: two stylized fish in circular frame

technical_features.material: Calfskin vellum with smooth, well-prepared surface; uniform thickness; faint folio numbering visible
technical_features.preservation_condition: Overall excellent: pigments vibrant with minimal flaking; slight discoloration at outer margins; gold leaf remains burnished
notable_physical_characteristics: Visible underdrawing in pen strokes under pigments
Pricked and ruled guide lines for text and marginal elements

functional_analysis.primary_function: Private devotion: calendar page in a Book of Hours
secondary_functions: Visual aide-mémoire for saints’ feast days
Display of patron’s wealth through luxurious materials
functional_analysis.intended_audience: Individual patron of noble status for personal use

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This February calendar page, likely produced in a mid-14th-century Paris workshop, exemplifies the luxurious material and iconographic programme typical of high-end Books of Hours. The combination of the labour-of-the-month motif with its companion zodiac sign reflects the medieval integration of agrarian cycles and astrological symbolism into personal devotional practice. The use of burnished gold leaf for both the large historiated initial and the marginal medallions demonstrates the manuscript’s role as a status object, while the restrained palette of azurite blue, vermillion red, and leaf green reveals a sophisticated approach to colour hierarchy and layering. The Gothic textura quadrata script, with its precise rubrication, indicates a professional scriptorium hand, likely commissioned by a wealthy patron. Technically, the visible underdrawing and raised gesso ground under the gold point to advanced workshop practices, enabling crisp contours and luminous surfaces. Iconographically, the kneeling figure warming his hands by the brazier conveys seasonal toil in a manner coherent with contemporaneous calendar cycles, while the Pisces fish affirm the astrological dimension of timekeeping. Comparatively, this page shares stylistic affinities with the Hours of Jeanne d’Évreux, suggesting either direct influence or participation in the same artistic milieu. The integration of secular imagery within a devotional context exemplifies the broader cultural trend toward personalized piety fused with courtly visual refinement.
